Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Grant: Total Energy Expenditure in Apes Measured Using Doubly Labeled Water

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
All organisms must expend energy to accomplish the essential physiological tasks of growth, maintenance, and reproduction. Previous work has shown that species often vary in the amount of energy spent on these tasks, and that this variation has very important effects on species' ecology and pace of life. If we are to fully understand the evolved energetic and life-history strategies of ourselves and other related hominoid primates, it is necessary to acquire comparative data; at present, however, very little is known about the energy expenditure strategies of the living apes. This project will provide this structured comparative data on living apes through investigation of how much energy these species spend each day, and these energy expenditure measurements will be used to test the hypothesis that ape energy expenditures constrain their rates of growth, reproduction, and aging, and reflect their diet and ecology in the wild.

Total daily energy expenditure (calories/day) in apes (chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, orangutans, and gibbons) will be measured using a technique called the doubly labeled water (DLW) method. DLW tracks the body's rate of carbon dioxide production over a two-week period, which in turn provides an accurate measurement of the calories expended during that time; DLW is considered the gold-standard for measurements of daily energy expenditure. Using ape populations housed in Association of Zoos and Aquariums-accredited zoos, total daily energy expenditure will be measured among adult males and females using the DLW method. In addition to testing hypotheses regarding energy budgets, these measurements will advance the current understanding of the physiology and nutritional requirements of these species, as there are currently very few data available for ape energy expenditure.

Broader impacts of this project include a better understanding of the nutritional and metabolic requirements of apes, which may improve management strategies for captive apes and therefore improve the health and well-being of apes in captivity; obesity and other metabolic problems are a leading cause of illness in captive apes. This project also will strengthen and develop the role of U.S. zoos in basic research, and will provide research training and experience for undergraduates at Hunter College, Washington University, University of Cincinnati, and at other institutions near participating zoos. Finally, this project will increase public awareness of scientific research and its benefits, as information regarding the project will be made publicly available at participating zoos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All of life’s essential biological tasks - growth, reproduction, repair and maintenance, movement, digestion, and others –require energy. Understanding how an animal expends energy is therefore a powerful way of understanding its biology. Data from earlier studies of primate energy expenditure suggested a substantial degree of variation in energy expenditures in humans, apes, and other primates, but we lacked sufficient sample sizes to test for these differences. Such variation in energy expenditure would point to important ecological differences across species and would hold important implications for diet and metabolic health in humans and apes.

In this project, our main objective was to measure total daily energy expenditure (i.e., the total number of calories burned per day) in apes, including chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, orangutans, and gibbons, and to investigate whether and how daily energy expenditure in apes reflects variation in body size, activity level, diet, sex, and age. Further, we wanted to test whether ape species differed in their daily energy expenditures after accounting for factors such as body size and activity level.

We partnered with 13 zoos and 1 conservation center across the U.S. to conduct the energetics measurements. We employed the “doubly labeled water” method, a non-invasive and safe method for measuring energy expenditure during normal daily life. The doubly labeled water method was developed for human nutrition studies, and is considered the gold-standard for measuring energy expenditure in free-living subjects. Apes drank a small amount of water enriched in two rare, but safe, isotopes (deuterium and oxygen-18). A series of urine samples collected over a two-week period were then analyzed for isotope concentration, and these measurements were used to calculate average total daily energy expenditure. We also observed and recorded daily physical activity (e.g., walking, climbing, resting) during this two-week period. Ape data, along with human data collected previously in a different study, were used to compare energy expenditures across species.

 As expected, body size was the single best predictor of daily energy expenditure among apes. Activity levels were also correlated with daily energy expenditure, but the effect was modest. Age and sex did not have a measurable effect on metabolic rate in our sample.

Results also revealed a substantial degree of variation in total daily energy expenditure among humans and other ape species, even after controlling for the effects of body size and activity level. Humans exhibit the highest metabolic rates, followed in order by chimpanzees & bonobos, gorillas, and orangutans. These differences in energy expenditure do not appear to reflect dietary differences (one of our hypotheses at the outset of the study), but there is good evidence that these metabolic differences reflect differences in life history – the pace at which individuals grow, reproduce, and age. Humans’ greater energy expenditures accommodate our relatively high rates of reproduction and large, energetically costly brains; orangutans’ low metabolic rates are consistent with their extremely slow pace of life. These findings provide a physiological mechanism for the suite of unique human adaptations – large brains, fast reproduction, greater longevity – that have long eluded clear explanation.

We also found substantial differences in body composition among humans and apes. Humans are by far the fattest hominoid species, and the only one to exhibit a clear sex difference in body fat percentage (women have higher body fat percentage). Chimpanzees and bonobos had very low body fat percentages, and gorillas and orangutans were somewhat higher.
